journal-meta.journal-title: The Journal of Strain Analysis for Engineering Design

title-group.article-title: Local compliance, stress concentrations and strength in orthotropic materials

article-meta.aff: 1Aerospace Convergence Technology Research Division, Korean Aerospace Research Institute, Republic of Korea
2Department of Mechanical Engineering Education, Andong National University, Republic of Korea
3Tendering and Project Management Department, Power Systems Manufacturing, USA (*Formerly USDA Forest Products Laboratory, USA)
4Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Wisconsin, USA

author-notes.corresp: Robert E Rowlands, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Wisconsin, 1415 Engineering Drive, Madison, WI 53706, USA. Email: rowlands@engr.wisc.edu

abstract.p: Reducing tensile stress concentrations at geometric discontinuities in composites by altering the neighboring structural compliance, and the possible influence on strength, are investigated. Compared with the reduction in stress concentration, results show that increases in strength when introducing auxiliary holes can be appreciable in highly orthotropic natural composites such as wood but minimal in man-made aerospace-type structural composites. Although stress concentration might be a measure of structural integrity, assuming that a specific value of a stress concentration factor necessarily leads to failure can be erroneous. A scheme for optimizing size and location of auxiliary holes to minimize stress concentrations is included.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Engineering components often involve geometric discontinuities and it can be desirable to minimize the relevant stress concentrations. This study emphasizes reducing tensile stress concentrations in perforated or notched orthotropic materials, and the possible influence on strength, by reducing the adjacent structural stiffness through introducing nearby auxiliary geometric discontinuities. Comparative effects of filling these auxiliary geometric discontinuities with a compliant material (i.e. creating a functionally graded material), or replacing a central, plus two adjacent auxiliary, holes by an oblong-shaped/elliptical/slotted opening are considered. Results are included for fiber-reinforced aerospace-type composites (glass/epoxy (
G ℓ
/E), graphite/epoxy (Gr/E), graphite/aluminum (Gr/
A ℓ
) and boron/epoxy (B/E)) and a highly orthotropic natural composite, wood (Sitka Spruce). Unless otherwise stated, the strongest/stiffest direction of material symmetry coincides with that of the external loading. A method is presented for optimizing the size and location of auxiliary geometric discontinuities to minimize the tensile stress concentration factor (TSCF).

Under static loading, reducing stress concentrations might not be too important with ductile isotropic materials in that local yielding is often not catastrophic. However, under cyclic conditions, reducing tensile stress concentrations can be important in even isotropic materials which behave in a ductile manner when loaded statically. Composites typically do not exhibit ‘traditional’ yielding, and stress concentrations can be important.

A large amount of information is available regarding the stresses around single or multiple holes or notches in isotropic elastic bodies. The solution for a single row of holes in an infinite isotropic plate was obtained by Howland1 and for a uniaxially loaded finite-width isotropic plate by Schultz.2 Peterson3 and Savin4 summarize results for numerous geometric discontinuities in isotropic members. Cook and Young5 discuss the concept of decreasing stress concentrations in isotropic members by using an elliptical hole rather than separate auxiliary holes. The concept of reducing the stress concentration around a hole in a loaded isotropic plate by introducing auxiliary circular holes was demonstrated at least as early as 1952 by Heywood.6 Erickson and Riley7 and Kajonvorawatanakul8 subsequently used photoelasticity to determine the optimum locations and sizes of the auxiliary holes to minimize the stress concentration associated with circular holes in isotropic polyester resin (Homolite 100) plates. Spotts et al.9 discuss how one can improve an original design by removing material, whereas Kan and Ilumoka10 use boundary elements to optimize the design of an isotropic tensile plate containing three holes.

The increased use of composites heightens the need for stress and strength knowledge in orthotropic materials containing holes or notches. Although orthotropic behavior can produce extremely high stress concentrations, relatively little (at least analytical) stress information appears to be available for multiple neighboring geometric discontinuities in finite composite members. Kosmodamiansky11 studied the stresses in a loaded infinite orthotropic laminate containing two holes of different size and gave the first approximate stress distribution around the contour of the smaller hole. Lin and Ueng12 subsequently evaluated the stresses in an infinite composite containing two identical elliptical holes. Stress concentrations in an infinite, anisotropic laminate weakened by multiple collinear holes are available from Fan and Wu13. Research14–44 contains information on local structural stiffness, stress concentrations and/or strength for a variety of situations. The above mentioned studies include cases where the stress fields of neighboring holes interact with each other, or one modifies the fiber orientation/density locally or otherwise changes the reinforcement/softening at or near a geometric discontinuity.
Stresses are predicted here using ANSYS and Gerhardt’s hybrid FEA.45,46

ℓ

Table 3 shows that optimizing the location and size of a pair of symmetrically-positioned auxiliary holes about a central hole reduces the TSCFs at the original central hole in the uniaxially loaded plates by 21.2% (isotropy), 22.1% (glass/epoxy), 23.2% (graphite/aluminum), 29.3% (graphite/epoxy) and 30.9% (boron/epoxy), respectively, compared to those without auxiliary holes. These uniaxially loaded members of Tables 2 and 3, and Figures 2 and 3, all have
W
= 5.08 cm and
c / W
= 0.5. Corresponding results could be quite different for other values of
c / W
, different types of loading and/or a different material. At least for the cases considered here, the stress concentration relief realized by introducing the auxiliary holes tends to increase with increased orthotropy, E11/E22. This could be significant in that TSCFs in composites often increase with increased orthotropy. Evaluation of the appropriate values of
ℓ
0
and
d
0
to optimize/minimize the tensile stress concentration factors as a function of
W
and/or
c
would necessitate repeating this approach for various values of
W
and/or
c
. While the present analyses optimize the size and locations of auxiliary holes about an original hole, a similar type analysis could be conducted for auxiliary edge notches about an original notch. In the case of the auxiliary holes, the maximum tangential stress typically occurs at values of θ slightly less than 90o, Figure 4.46

caption.p: Finite-width uniaxially loaded tensile plates containing (a) a circular hole, (b) three circular holes, (c) an elliptical hole and (d) three circular holes in which the auxiliary holes are filled with a relatively compliant material.

sec.title: General comments
sec.p:
Results of Table 3 indicate that for optimum conditions, the central and auxiliary holes can intersect. This raises the prospect of using, if otherwise acceptable, an elliptical/slotted or oval-shaped opening instead of three circular holes. Open auxiliary holes might not be acceptable in some engineering applications (e.g. fluid containers), motivating one to consider auxiliary holes filled with a material which is more compliant than the original/surrounding material. An example is considered that involves an elliptical opening whose major diameter = (2
ℓ
+ d) and minor diameter =
c
, Figure 4(c). Cases in which the auxiliary circular holes are filled with a relatively compliant material are also evaluated, Figure 4(d) and Table 4. Slotted, rather than elliptical, holes might be easier to machine. Table 5 compares the effect on stress concentrations of using a slotted hole instead of a single circular hole.

sec.title: Geometry and material properties
sec.p:
Geometries for a uniaxially loaded finite-width T2A/HX593 Gr/E composite (Hexal Corp.) containing a single circular hole, three circular holes, an elliptical hole or three circular holes in which the auxiliary circular holes are filled with a relatively compliant material, are indicated in Figure 4. Using a procedure somewhat similar to that associated with Figures 2 and 3, but employing the pre-selected value of
ℓ
= 3.556 cm as influenced by results of Table 2, values of d = 2.294 and Max-
σ
t
/
σ
c
= 0.73 cm were obtained for this material for
W
= 5.08 cm and
c / W
= 0.5. For these dimensions, the auxiliary and central holes of Table 4 will not intersect. The compliant material filling the auxiliary holes is either a urethane rubber (
E
= 3.10 MPa,
ν
= 0.46), polycarbonate (
E
= 2.48 GPa,
ν
= 0.38) or epoxy (
E
= 3.36 GPa,
ν
= 0.38).

FEM analyses for the tensile composite containing either the elliptical hole of Figure 4(c) and Table 4, or three circular holes with compliantly-filled auxiliary holes, Figure 4(d), in the T2A/HX593 Gr/E are based on these above values of
ℓ
and d.46 Perfect bonding was assumed between the contents of the auxiliary holes and the composite, and any triaxial effects at the interface were ignored. Utilizing the present values of d and
ℓ
as those employed previously for the empty auxiliary holes, the elliptical hole has major radius (
ℓ
+ d/2) = (3.556 cm + 1.147 cm) = 4.703 cm and minor radius
c / 2
= 1.27 cm, Figure 4(c).

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
Results of these Max-
σ
t
/
σ
c
and reductions in TSCF are shown in Table 4. Probably not surprisingly, these data illustrate that the elliptical hole of Figure 4(c) introduces the minimum stress concentration. At least for the present material and
W
= 5.08 cm and
c
= 2.54 cm, the reduced tensile stress concentration due to an equivalent elliptical hole is 80% better than symmetrically locating empty auxiliary circular holes in the neighborhood of the original circular hole. Stress-wise, filling the auxiliary holes with a fairly compliant material is almost as good as using empty auxiliary holes (Pilkey and Pilkey3 treat compliantly filled elliptical holes in isotropic materials). Rowlands et al.47 describe B/E composites containing either a central circular or elliptical hole (latter’s minor diameter equals that of the circular hole and is transverse to the loading direction). The elliptically-perforated plates had a 28.4% lower TSCF (based on gross area) and were 26.8% stronger than those having a round hole. The TSCF for the slotted hole of Table 5 is 45% less than that for the circular hole.

sec.title: Effects of material directions
sec.p:
Unless stated otherwise, all results presented are for cases where the strongest/stiffest direction of material symmetry coincides with the direction of external loading. However, Figure 5 compares the ANSYS-predicted tensile stressFigure 5.
Effects of fiber orientation on maximum tensile,
K
t
, and compressive,
K
c

Δ K

c
=

=
ℓ
=
W
/2 = 2.54 cm). concentration factors,
K
t, and their reductions,
Δ K
t, associated with introducing auxiliary holes, in a uniaxially-loaded, centrally perforated boron/epoxy (properties of Table 1) tensile plate when the strongest/stiffest 1-direction of material symmetry is either parallel or perpendicular, respectively, to the direction of loading. While the TSCF (at the central hole),
K
c
t
, for only a central hole is substantially less when the stiffest direction of material symmetry is perpendicular to the direction of loading (4.31 vs. 8.42), the reduction in this concentration factor,
Δ
K
c
t
, due to adding auxiliary holes is also less when the stiffest direction of material symmetry is perpendicular to the loading direction (15.5% vs. 29%). The composite would be weaker in the more-compliant 2-direction.

The relative size and locations of the auxiliary holes for the cases of Figure 5 were not optimized, but rather motivated by previous experience (for strongest/stiffest 1-direction parallel to the loading) for the same values of
c
=
d
=
ℓ
=
W / 2
= 2.54 cm. Even keeping identical values of
W
and
c
, and the same material, individual rigorous optimizations (of size and location of auxiliary holes) would be needed for each of the two different material-directions of Figure 5. Nevertheless, even when the weakest/most compliant material orientations of Figure 5 coincide with the direction of
σ
0
, the TSCFs at the central,
K
c
t
= 3.64, and auxiliary,
K
a
t
= 3.66, holes are close to each other. This suggests the locations and size of the auxiliary holes are almost optimized.

The
Δ
K
c
t
= 29% of Figure 5 represents the difference between the value of the TSCF at the (original) central hole without (
K
c
t
= 8.42), and with (
K
c
t
= 6.00), the auxiliary holes, normalized with respect to the original TSCF at the central hole, times 100. The
Δ
K
a
t
= 23.5% of Figure 5 is based on the value of the TSCF at the (original) central hole without the auxiliary holes (
K
c
t
= 8.42) and that at the auxiliary holes (
K
a
t
= 6.44), normalized by the original TSCF at the central hole, times 100. For completeness, Figure 5 also includes the compressive stress concentration factors, Kc.

sec.title: Notched plates
sec.p:
This study emphasizes centrally-perforated composites. Nevertheless, Figure 6 compares the reductions in ANSYS-predicted TSCFs in a centrally-perforated and a side-notched boron/epoxy (B/E properties of Table 1) tensile member associated with introducing auxiliary holes or notches (Pilkey and Pilkey3 treat multiple edge notches in isotropic materials). As discussed relative to the analyses associated with Figure 5, each of the perforated and notched cases of Figure 6 would require its own optimization with respect to the size and location of auxiliary geometries (holes or notches). No deliberate effort was made here to optimize either case of Figure 6. Rather, the sizes and locations of auxiliary holes and notches are again based on d = c = ℓ = W/2 = 2.54 cm for both geometries of Figure 6. While not optimizing the auxiliary features of Figure 6 (particularly for the side notches), and using common values of c and ℓ, the reduction in TSCF at the central geometric discontinuity,
Δ
K
c
t
, achieved for side notches (33%) slightly exceeds that (29%) for the central hole (ΔK computed as in Figure 5). However, not optimizing the geometry results in the TSCFs at the auxiliary holes (6.44 vs. 6.0) and notches (6.08 vs. 5.02) exceeding that at the central discontinuity of the respective three-hole/notch geometries. This study did not investigate whether such reductions in TSCFs would be accompanied by enhanced strength.

caption.p:
Maximum tensile stress concentration factors in perforated or notched uniaxially-loaded B/E (material properties of Table 1) tensile members and their reductions with auxiliary holes or notches (
c
=

/2 = 2.54 cm).

sec.title: Effects of local compliance changes on stresses and strength
Graphite/epoxy
sec.p:
Tables 5 and 6 contain the results of centrally-perforated, uniaxially-loaded (in their strongest/stiffest direction) Gr/E composites whose TSCFs are reduced by decreasing the local stiffness through geometric changes. The stress concentration factors were again predicted using ANSYS. The
Δ K
t values associated with these Gr/E specimens were calculated as in Figures 5 and 6. That
K
c
t
and
K
a
t
in Table 6 differ from each other for the three-hole geometry again demonstrates lack of optimization. Holes in the [05/90/05] Gr/E specimens of Table 6 were prepared by EDM (electrical discharge machining). Standard deviations (SD) of the measured strengths are noted in Table 6. Although introducing the auxiliary holes provides an 18.3% reduction in the predicted TSCF at the central hole, the strengths are unchanged, Table 6. Symmetrically-locating a pair of auxiliary holes around a central circular hole in a very limited number of [05/90/05] Gr/E specimens (data omitted) did show some increase in strength. However, all of these holes were drilled and the strengths of these drilled specimens (both single- and three-hole) were much lower than the EDM-prepared specimens of Table 6.

Stress concentrations and strengths in uniaxially-loaded [05/90/05] Gr/E tensile members with EDM-prepared holes (

fn.p: Based on gross area; ( ) ** standard deviation.

sec.p: Figure 7 is a photograph of a failed [05/90/05] Gr/E specimen of Table 6. These Gr/E specimens tended to fail longitudinally, initiating at the edge of a hole, i.e. parallel to the dominant fiber direction. This observed mode of failure reinforces the above hypothesis that strength of the perforated Gr/E is influenced by more than just the TSCF or local tensile stress distribution near the holes.

caption.p: Failed [05/90/05] Gr/E specimen of Table 6 containing a central plus auxiliary circular holes.

sec.title: Glass/epoxy
sec.p:
Two [0/90/010/90/0] glass/epoxy tensile composites (
E
11
= 34.2 GPa,
E
22
= 14.1 GPa,
G
12
= 3.4 GPa and
ν
12
= 0.22) of the general geometry of Figure 1 (
W
= 2.61 cm, length = 34.53 cm and thickness = 0.32 cm) were tested, Figure 8. Unlike the previously tested [05/90/05] Gr/E specimens, and admittedly not a sought situation in practice, these
G ℓ
/E samples were loaded perpendicular to the strongest/stiffest composite orientation. The specimen of Figure 8(a) contained only a central, circular hole with
c / W
= 0.49. The right-hand composite (Figure 8(b)) had an identical central hole (
c / W
= 0.49) plus two symmetrically located auxiliary holes. The central and auxiliary holes of these G/E specimens did not intersect. Measured
G ℓ
/E strengths are 4143 N (931lb) for the single-perforated specimen and 4606 N) for the three-hole composite. The latter represents an 11% increase in strength over the single-hole specimen. Unlike the Gr/E (Figure 7), these
G ℓ
/E (Figure 8) specimens fractured largely in tension (probably not surprising, recognizing the fiber layup) across the transverse ligament adjacent to a hole – although some longitudinal splitting is observed in Figure 8(b).

caption.p:
Failed longitudinally-loaded [90/0/9010/0/90] glass/epoxy composite tensile specimens containing (a) an original central circular hole (
W
= 2.61cm,
c / W
= 0.49) without and (b) with symmetrically located auxiliary holes (
ℓ / W
= 0.68,
d / W
= 0.43).

sec.p: Both hybrid FEA and ANSYS were used (assuming homogeneous, plane-stress) to predict the stress concentrations in the perforated specimens of Figure 8.46 The values of the maximum TSCFs (based on uniform far-field stress) for these two plates by these methods are shown in Table 7. The nominal 16% reduction in the TSCF at the central hole is accompanied by the previously mentioned 11% increase in strength.

sec.p:
Unlike the longitudinally-loaded [05/90/05] Gr/E of Table 6 (loaded parallel to the ten 0-degree fiber plies), reducing stiffness in the neighborhood of the central hole by adding auxiliary holes increased the strength (albeit with very limited data) of this transversely-loaded [0/90/010/90/0]
G ℓ
/E (loaded transversely to the twelve 0-degree fiber plies; parallel to the two 90-degree fiber plies). The different response on strength of reducing the TSCF by adding auxiliary holes to these Gr/E and
G ℓ
/E laminated composites might reflect deficiencies in assuming plane-stress homogeneity and/or the complexity of the items influencing laminate strength, i.e. strength controlled by more than just the TSCF.

sec.title: Stress concentrations and strength
sec.p:
Previous materials considered here are man-made, aerospace-type composites having fairly discrete fibers in a matrix. The ability to reduce TSCFs, and thereby potentially increase strength, through controlling local compliance by introducing auxiliary holes in a highly orthotropic natural material, wood (Sitka Spruce), was also evaluated, Figure 9 and Table 8.
E
11
= 11.45 GPa is a measured value for the Spruce tested here, whereas E22/E11 = 0.078, G12/E11 = 0.064 and
ν
12
= 0.37 are from the Wood Handbook.48 Recognizing variability in wood properties, relevant Spruce stresses were evaluated here for E11 ranging from 11.17 GPa to 11.70 GPa, while retaining E22/E11 = 0.078, G12/E11 = 0.064 and
ν
12
= 0.37. Changes in ANSYS-predicted stresses are very small over this range of
E
11
. Lack of available tooling sizes again hampered optimizing the size of the auxiliary holes in the Sitka Spruce. Rather, the selected values of
d / W
and
ℓ / W
of these Spruce specimens were influenced by the experiences with the other materials previously considered here. The Spruce specimens (23 cm long by 0.5 cm thick) lie in the longitudinal-radial plane, and were loaded parallel to the grain (longitudinal- or 1-direction). The wood was pre-conditioned to 12% moisture content and the holes carefully drilled using sharp brad-point bits, followed by reaming.

= 0.37).

sec.p:
The reduction in the TSCF at the original/central hole shown in Table 8 associated with adding the auxiliary holes is

= 4.91 for the three-hole geometry of Table 8 reflects the lack of exact optimization. The Spruce specimens were loaded at 0.13 cm/minute using an Instron tensile machine. All measured strengths of Table 8 are based on a minimum of 18 specimens/tests. The standard deviations (SD) of these strengths are noted in Table 8.

The increase in Spruce strength of specimens of Table 8 having auxiliary holes is 95% of the concomitant reduction in TSCF at the central hole. Although the strength of the transversely-loaded [0/90/010/90/0]
G ℓ
/E of Figure 8, and that of a very few (unreported here) tested three-hole [05/90/05] Gr/E specimens having drilled holes, increases when auxiliary holes are added, their relative strength enhancements do not approach that achieved here for the Spruce.

Analyses. Figure10 demonstrates the increased amount of the Spruce material throughout which
σ
11
≥
S
u
= 70.8 MPa (at σo = Sn) upon adding the auxiliary holes, whereas Figure 11 illustrates the corresponding redistribution of
σ
11
. The latter stress distribution is reasonably influenced by the TSCF associated with the auxiliary holes. While decreasing the TSCF at the central hole and increasing strength, introducing the auxiliary holes increases the amount of material adjacent to the central hole which is stressed beyond the material’s unnotched strength,
S
u
= 70.8 MPa, Figure 10. Subjecting more material to high stresses (as occurs here when auxiliary holes are present) could be detrimental if these high stresses inadvertently encountered some other stress raiser or strength degradation such as a local grain deviation or material variation. This can readily happen with ‘natural’ composites like wood.

sec.p:
Figure 11 and the stress concentrations of Table 8 demonstrate how the auxiliary holes somewhat ‘soften’ the severity of the stresses surrounding the three-hole combination, compared with that for the single-perforated case. This is not unlike the predicted situation around the elliptical hole in the Spruce tensile plate of Figures 12 and 13. The minor diameter H = 0.5
W
of the elliptical hole of Figures 12 and 13 is equal to the diameter of the central hole, whereas the ellipse’s major diameter is equal to (2
ℓ + d
= 1.4 W + 0.42 W) = 1.82 W of the Spruce specimens of Table 8 and Figures 9 and 11. The TSCF at the edge of this elliptical hole of Figures 12 and 13 is only 3.73, compared with 5.70 (Table 8) at the central hole of the three-hole geometry. This is 47% less than that for the single circularly-perforated Spruce of Table 8 and Figures 9 through 11, and is compatible with results for the elliptical holes of Table 4 and Rowlands et al.47 and the slotted hole of Table 5.

in Sitka Spruce (material properties of Table 8) tensile member of Figure 12.

sec.p: Like the tested [05/90/05] Gr/E, most Spruce specimens exhibited some early longitudinal failure starting at a hole, rather than in tension across the ligament extending transversely from a hole, Figures 14 and 15. However, Figure 15 also shows some transverse failures (including one extending from the edge of the hole). These data for Spruce might suggest that, even though increases in strength accompany reduced TSCFs, stress concentrations themselves are not the major (or only significant) issue controlling strength – and perhaps this demonstrates it would be better to apply a multiaxial strength/failure theory around (and in the neighborhood of) the boundary of the hole. Of course the behavior in materials like wood can be influenced by any grain deviations.

caption.p: Failed Sitka Spruce specimen of Figures 9 through 11 and Table 8 containing only a central hole.
Failed Sitka Spruce specimen of Figures 9 through 11, 15 and Table 8 containing a central plus auxiliary holes.

sec.title: Summary, discussion and conclusions
sec.p: The reduced tensile stress concentrations in perforated or notched orthotropic materials associated with altering the structural stiffness locally, and any changes in the strength, are studied. Being unaware of any commercial software for reducing stress concentrations in perforated components made of an anisotropic material, a finite element based approach was developed for doing so by optimizing the size and location of auxiliary holes. Although the reduction in predicted TSCF tends to increase with increased orthotropy and can exceed 30% for highly orthotropic materials, the strength enhancement can be significantly less than the reduction in tensile stress concentration. Filling the auxiliary holes with a compliant material reduces the stress concentration enhancement only slightly, compared with empty auxiliary holes. Some issues considered here have been studied previously for isotropy, but prior investigations involving such optimization for orthotropic composites do not seem to be available. The presently studied laminated composites have a relatively simple stacking sequence.

At least for the cases considered, the optimum geometry using auxiliary holes typically involves the latter having a diameter and hole spacing which are approximately equal to the diameter of the original, central hole. An in-line elliptical/slotted hole whose major diameter has a length comparable to that of a central, plus two auxiliary, holes results in a significantly smaller tensile stress concentration than for just the original circular hole whose diameter equals the minor diameter of the ellipse. This is not surprising and is perhaps at least partially due to the radius at the ends of the minor diameter of the elliptical cutout being greater than that of the central hole of the corresponding three-hole case. The observed stress concentration reductions associated with adding auxiliary holes, or other wise reducing the neighboring compliance ‘fore and aft’ of a central circular perforation in a tensile member, causes the combination of original, plus auxiliary, holes to approach mechanically (stress-wise) that of an ellipse whose major axis parallels the direction of the applied load. Introducing the auxiliary holes about a central hole increases the effective fillet radius at the highly tensile-stressed locations of the original hole. Other things being equal, perforated composites with longitudinal elliptical holes are also stronger than those with comparable circular holes.

If the diameter and locations of the auxiliary holes are optimized, then all three holes might have essentially the same diameter, as can happen here, and hole interaction can occur. If not discounted for other reasons, it could therefore be informative to consider the relative merits of an oval (slotted or cigar-shaped) hole instead of an elliptical opening relative to relieving stress concentrations. Slotted shapes can be easier than elliptical holes to machine. Although not verified under orthotropy, an alternative consideration might be to simulate an elliptical hole by a series of circular holes of decreasing diameter.5

The present approach of utilizing auxiliary and/or non-circular holes to reduce local stresses is an alternative to providing a doubler. In addition to decreasing local stresses, adding auxiliary holes can be fiscally attractive by saving material and weight. Doublers, in addition to adding material/weight and machining/fabrication operations, protrude beyond the surface. The latter can be undesirable. Depending on the situation, adding additional holes around an existing hole might be unsuitable. However, the general concept of somehow modifying the structural stiffness in the neighborhood of a cutout in a composite (be it by modifying the neighboring geometry, providing empty or compliantly-filled auxiliary holes or locally controlling the fiber orientation/spacing) can be helpful.14–29

Stresses were predicted by Gerhardt’s hybrid finite element approach and/or ANSYS.45,46 The hybrid FEA is extremely appealing for the present situations involving multiple neighboring geometric discontinuities in members having widely varying geometry and orthotropy. ANSYS, while highly developed, necessitates many small elements around each cutout.

The observed possibility to increase strength by reducing the TSCF in man-made aerospace-type composites is somewhat mixed. While introducing auxiliary holes about a central hole in the Gr/E laminate of Table 6 reduced the TSCF by 18% without any change in strength, the B/E composite of Rowlands et al.47 exhibited both a reduction in TSCF and increase in strength of approximately 27% upon replacing a circular hole by an elliptical hole. The limited information on the transversely loaded [0/90/010/90/0] glass/epoxy composite of Figure 8 also showed increased strength with reduced TSCF. Information of Table 6 for Gr/E, and Table 8 and Figures 10 and 11 for Spruce, exhibit some differences in behavior. Unlike the Gr/E, the fact that the strength enhancement in the Sitka Spruce approaches the TSCF reduction suggests stress concentrations themselves might not be the critical issue. Rather, the competition between orthotropic strengths and stresses around (and beyond) the hole could necessitate (among other considerations) at least a multiaxial strength/failure analysis.

We do not have a definite explanation as to why the natural composite, Sitka Spruce, exhibits such a greater strength enhancement (relative to reduction in TSCFs) than do the more discrete fiber-matrix aerospace-type composites considered. While the increase in strength of perforated tensile wood specimens when adding auxiliary holes essentially equals the associated reduction in the TSCF, introducing auxiliary holes in centrally-perforated Gr/E results in virtually no increase in strength, despite a reduced tensile stress concentration. The E11/E22 ratio for these two materials is not highly different, being 14.6 for the tested [05/90/05] Gr/E and 12.8 for the wood. Both the Gr/E specimens of Table 6 and Sitka Spruce specimens of Table 8 have c/W = 0.5. In addition to the possible presence or absence of interlaminar stresses, the lack of meaningful strength enhancement accompanying the reduced TSCF in composites such as the [05/90/05] Gr/E compared with that of wood might be at least partially associated with local (or micro-mechanical) effects due to the more discrete nature of the former man-made laminate compared with natural composites such as wood. Local (or micro) effects associated with the more highly discrete nature of the man-made [05/90/05] Gr/E composites compared with natural cellulosic composites may play a role in how stresses at and near a cutout influence strength. The relative ratios of fiber-to-matrix moduli could also contribute. The fiber-to-matrix modulus ratio of discrete artificially manufactured aerospace composites such as
G ℓ
/E, Gr/E, B/E and Kevlar/E typically ranges between 20 and 150. The corresponding ratio for cellulose ‘fibers’ in a lignin-hemicellulose ‘matrix’ can approach 800.49–51 Interestingly, although the amount of test data are somewhat limited, tensile paper (2.13 ≤ E11/E22≤ 3.05) specimens containing a single central circular, plus symmetrically-located auxiliary, holes were stronger than those having only the single hole.42 The paper material was loaded in the 1-direction. No major effort was made to optimize the geometry (size, spacing) of the auxiliary holes, and failures occurred at the auxiliary holes. Assuming linear elastic constitutive paper response, FEM-predicted Kt at the auxiliary holes exceeded that at the central hole. Failures were longitudinal tensile along the ligament extending transversely from these auxiliary holes.

Whereas the [05/90/05] Gr/E specimens of Table 6 show no strength enhancement compared with their decreased TSCF, preformed perforated composites can exhibit a substantial strength increase, along with a reduced TSCF, compared to specimens having drilled holes. By preforming the holes, Gunderson and Lute increased the fiber content adjacent to the hole in the region of the maximum tensile stress.17 This preforming process also avoids cutting fibers and the local damage which typically accompanies drilled holes. In this regard, the holes in the [05/90/05] Gr/E specimens of Table 6 were prepared by EDM, while those in the [0/90/010/90/0]
G ℓ
/E (Figure 8) and the Spruce (Table 8, Figures 9 through 11, 14 and 15) were drilled (the drilled holes in the Spruce were also subsequently reamed). The strengths of the EDM-prepared [05/90/05] Gr/E specimens of Table 6 show much greater scatter than do the drilled and reamed Spruce specimens of Table 8.

Stress concentration factors were predicted here assuming plane stress, linear elasticity and material homogeneity. The current data present some seeming contradictions, and certainly the items causing failure in perforated composites are complicated. Some of the composite materials evaluated exhibit an increased strength with the reduced tensile stress concentration, while some do not. This raises the question as to how strongly are these two factors really connected, i.e. stress concentrations might provide indicators of the strength degradation associated with a geometric discontinuity, and thus perhaps a measure of component integrity; however, there need not be direct causes and effect. Results suggest stress concentrations may be a reasonable predictor of relative strength for isotropic materials (particularly if yielding is absent) and macro-homogeneous composites such as wood and paper, but not necessarily for laminates consisting of stacked plies at several different orientations.

Future studies might consider (i) combining an extensive test program and 3-D stress analyses (accounting for individual plies where applicable), possibly with a strength criterion applicable around/beyond the edge of the discontinuities; (ii) other loading (e.g. biaxial, in-plane bending, compression) and geometric conditions (different ratios of W/c, etc.) so as to assess if there are any scale effects; (iii) different orthotropic and/or composite materials (including laminated wood and paper plies), involving more complicated stacking sequences and hybrid laminates; (iv) the possibilities of applying the concepts to fatigue and impact conditions, and continue applications to buckling; (v) continuing to enhance processing abilities to locally control fiber orientation and/or content and thereby improve performance (through enhanced design, better manufacturing, e.g. automated tape-laying machines, electromagnetically rotating/moving fibers and utilizing biomimicry) in components containing geometric discontinuities; (vi) investigating why reducing the TSCFs in some situations (materials) shows significant strength enhancement while not in others; (vii) using techniques such as X-ray to ascertain hopefully why the aerospace-type structural composites seemingly behaved so differently here than say wood or paper; (viii) the feasibility of improving the performance of components containing side notches by extending the present concept of minimizing stress concentrations through local changes in geometry, e.g., adding auxiliary notches; (ix) applying current concepts to materials whose constitutive relations are nonlinear or inelastic; and (x) developing a more direct method than utilized here for optimizing the size and locations of auxiliary holes (notches) and/or to otherwise minimize stress concentrations, e.g. use of genetic algorithm approaches such as in Cho26 and Cho and Rowlands.27,28

Regarding the latter comment, stress concentrations may not sufficiently tell the story in laminates consisting of stacked plies of different orientations; however they could be effective for isotropic materials (particularly in the absence of yielding) and composite materials which are more homogeneous at the macro scale. As well as reducing a tensile stress concentration factor, adding angle-plies to a cross-ply type laminate could make the material more ductile and reduce the structural seriousness of the stress concentration factor. As occurred here, the correct size tooling might not be available with which to prepare the optimized size auxiliary holes. Some knowledge of the practical variations in size and/or locations of auxiliary holes to provide approximate optimization could therefore be informative. For example, adding auxiliary holes to the Spruce (Table 8) and paper (Considine et al.42) specimens significantly enhanced strength, even though the size and/or locations of the auxiliary holes were not optimized. Any test program should consider employing a common (or controlled) method of preparing the holes or notches, as well as sufficient number of replications.
